description: Originally two words; from Old English on (“a (preposition)”) sundran (“separate position”), from Proto-Germanic *sunder, *sundraz. Cognate with Danish sønder, Swedish sönder, Dutch zonder, German sonder, Icelandic sundur, Faroese sundur and Norwegian sunder/sønder; akin to Gothic 𐍃𐌿𐌽𐌳𐍂𐍉 (sundrō).

adverbs.description: asunder (comparative more asunder, superlative most asunder)

entries.meaning: (archaic, literary) Into separate parts or pieces.
examples: Lest anyone find her treasure, she tore the map asunder and cast its pieces into the wind.
